Translation: A tired woman is eating in the room.
A tired woman is eating in the room.
Comment: Bare roots as attributive modifiers can only be postnominal.

Translation: A woman tired of work is eating in the room.
Comment: The ungrammaticality is because bare roots used as attributive modifiers cannot take dependents.

Translation: This woman is tired.
Comment: To function as independent predicates, bare roots must take verbal personal markers (prefixes).

Translation: This woman is tired.
Comment: Bare roots cannot function as independent predicates. However, this is ungrammatical only as a sentence, not as a DP.

Translation: This woman is tired of work.
Comment: The word order with the dependent following the “adjective” (root with a verbal personal marker) seems to be the neutral/more natural one, but the alternative word order is possible as well.

Translation: This woman is tired of work.
A tired woman is eating in the room.
Comment: Forms with the adjectivizer/relativizer -va can also function as attributive modifiers and they are normally placed postnominally.

Translation: A tired woman is eating in the room.
Comment: When used as attributive modifiers, the va-forms can also occur prenominally.

Original: Peteĩ kuña ikane’õva omba’apógui okaru kotýpe.
Morphemic: peteĩ kuña ikane’õ-va o-mba’apo=gui o-karu koty=pe
Translation: A woman tired of work is eating in the room.
Comment: N_V_XP seems to be the natural/more natural word order, but the alternative order N_XP_V is possible as well.

Original: Peteĩ kuña omba’apógui ikane’õva okaru kotýpe.
Morphemic: peteĩ kuña o-mba’apo=gui ikane’õ-va  o-karu koty=pe
Translation: A woman tired of work is eating in the room.
Comment: "N_V_XP seems to be the natural/more natural word order
column10: but the alternative order N_XP_V is possible as well."

Translation: A woman tired of work is eating in the room.
Comment: The prenominal placement of a complex AP/RC is not possible independently of the linear position of the dependent.

Translation: A woman tired of work is eating in the room.
Comment: The prenominal placement of a complex AP/RC is not possible independently of the linear position of the dependent

Translation: a woman who saw a man
Comment: The marking of a human direct object with =pe indicate that this is a subject relative. Without such marking, word order can clarify the intended interpretation. Noun phrases that come before the subordinate va-form tend to be interpreted as subjects.

Translation: a woman who(m) a man saw
Comment: Word order clarifies the interpretation. The -va form is separated from the head noun by the subject in this object relative.

Translation: This woman is tired.
Comment: Forms with the suffix -va (adjectivizer/relativizer) cannot be used predicatively. However, this is ungrammatical only as a sentence, not as a DP.

Translation: The knife (that is) on the table is clean
Comment: The postnominal placement of adnominal PPs appears to be the neutral/more natural one. Such PPs are often introduced with an additional enclitic =gua.

Translation: The knife (that is) on the table is clean.
Comment: The prenominal placement of adnominal PPs is also possible in this example.

Translation: S/he saw a car without passengers / anyone inside.
Comment: possm.3 = possessed form of relational roots (for third-person pronominal possessor).

Translation: S/he saw a car without passengers / anyone inside.
Comment: In this example, prenominal placement of PPs is not possible. But it remains an open question is if this correlates with the presence/absence of =gua.

Translation: We will go towards our town on horses.
